transcript.content: Bono, you should be a weatherman, because once again you've predicted, uh, wrongly, it's n- it's not a beautiful day at all, is it Stephen?
That was U2, XFM 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Claire Sturgess.
Claire Sturgess in for Karl Pilkington.
Sunning himself. Where- where has he gone, Mauritius, was it?
I think, with um, uh, his girlfriend's parents.
You remember last week he was, uh, worried- they'd never been abroad and, uh, her dad was saying, "How d- was- was way- best way

Karl's going, "You get them over there." And he's going, "We can put 'em in a jar." He goes, "Put 'em in a jar." I phoned him up in the week, uh, just before he went, I think Friday, I said uh, "Have a nice time." And uhh- Sunday, and he said, uh, "Guess what he's doing now?" I went, "What?" He said, "He's packing margarine."
My dad does that, my parents always take, uh, tea bags wherever they're going.
You know, for fear of- of there being some kind of tea bag drought in France.
Is it d- is it wrong- but I mean, I-
I don't know, is it because maybe English Breakfast tea you can't get over there? So it's-
'Cause frankly I- you know, you can take your-
Tea is probably the single most popular drink in the world.
I know, but what about the fore- the fancy foreign teas, your Earl Greys and the like.

'Cause I want good English Breakfast, don't bother me with Earl Grey, I don't know what that cup of tea is, it's not tea to me it's just- it's laughable, it's weak, it's pathetic, it's just- it's- eurgh!
I- d'you know what? Earl Grey with a little bit of skimmed milk isn't so bad.
And is your husband a fan?!
Sort of like, bant- banter, having a little go at each other!
Somet- Sometimes sort of pretending that, you know.
Sometimes pretending we're not close mates, you know, close personal friends, you know, and sometimes-
Yeah! And, uh all that innuendo and that, innit?
Oh, smutty, smutty, some of it.
(laughing) Yeah. And i- and the- and I... (unintelligible) freaky goggle-eyed thing.
I sometimes go too far, I do ruin it when I go t- uh, too far-
So let's be nice- well! Let's have a bit of Blur.
We're not out of time, we've got a whole
Hour and fifty minutes to go, on the Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant show, XFM 104.9.
I hope we have one of those after every record.
I think y- I think if you were actually like a proper DJ, if you actually tried to do the Dr. Fox thing, I think you'd be quite good.
But I- I think could only survive doing that, sort of um, post 11p.m., "Oooooh, quiet things down now, uh." I-I- I love all that.
Yeah, yeah, yeah, late sort of radio.
That sort of that- (laughing) yeah yeah yeah that talk- that 'American Jock' type thing as well.
It's on digital- I think it's radio for the over fifties.
And it plays all- it was Cli- it was playing Cliff Richards this morning, it played, um, Sammy Davis Jr., it played, um, Beatles - Here Comes The Sun, and I was loving it.
Well, it's aimed at your age group.
(laughing) Yeah, exactly! And I've got a bad back, I've been complaining of a bad back all week. He's been ill.
We have- we have work this week, he's been ill, off with the flu.

(coughs) I'm still not bad- I'll tell you this, I- I- I- j- uhh, Wednesday morning I think it was, I woke up, and I had the head, the sore throat, the aching body, and I- d'you know, I immediately thought I've got the SARS virus
To the doctors twice with him.
I've seriously sat in a waiting room within twice.
Well, I just, I just went up- I thou- I thought-
I thought oh God, I felt- felt them. I didn't need to do it then, did I? I du-
I naturally just touched my- but I-
We should point out- we should point out that uh Ricky's mother didn't die of testicular cancer. That it just-
No- no- no, no but I had a sort of thought, oh god well I've got it now and um, I think I went along once with testicular cancer, didn't I?
Yeah, you had the testis problem once, I remember--
Cause I remember sitting in the waiting room looking through uh, an old articles catalog with you, for some reason. I think it was the only think to read.
Then I think I thought I had throat cancer, didn't I?
Cause I think you had a bit of a (Steve mimics a cough)--
But then I think- no I think- I'm over that. I was just like, yeah, sent me a bit. So uh, but um yeah, I've just- It's just a bad back--
Why were you fiddling around down below? Cause I mean, it wasn't like, it wasn't like I called on you to do some work and you said, I've gotta rush to doctors. I think it was like lunchtime.
So you'd obviously been meddling around down there.
I've checked them a few times and I'm never sure.
Or can't you do that when you first get up, maybe before you make the bed?
Not- not in a restaurant when we're eating dinner.
That- that confused me. I don't know where me hands were.
You've put me right off me meatballs.
But Ricky just to clear it, you are okay, aren't you?
Yeah just a bad back. Yeah. Let's have a record, shall we? Bit of Bruce Springsteen would be lovely.
Turin Brakes and Pain Killer on Xfm 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Claire Sturgees.
Yeah, no, it's- it's good to be here.
I'm missing Kar- I'm missing hearing Karl actually--
Shouldn't have mentioned him cause people will remember then they'll go, "Oh yeah".
How are you, Sturgees? We've not really said hello to you.
I'm- I'm very well, thank you.
Do you look forward to these occasions when you get to stand in for Karl.
I do. I- I get a bit- little bit nervous.
Is it intimidating? I imagine it would be.
It is. No, it is a bit intimidating cause he's- cause he's such a funny man.
Um but, you know, once I'm here, I'm okay.
Yeah, but he doesn't- he doesn't know he is. It's not like he's doing it on purpose. It's- it's- you know what I mean? So--
He's- he's just nat- he's a natural--
At least you know what you're saying.
It's not all downhill is it?
No, no it'll be fine there's only an hour and a half to go, we'll be okay. Can we talk about um--
: Can we talk about the BAFTAS. I don't want to sort of go on about.
Steve and Ricky wind Claire up.
Ohh, I don't like to talk about them--
Whatcha wanna know? Whatcha wanna know?
But of course-- well I know how many you won.
We were all watching and listening.
Not- not- not everyone does though Claire- I mean--
How many did you win, Steve?
Do you mean this- this year and last? or?
It's two now. Two last year. Four in all
So it's four in all. Two of those are Ricky's. Specifically his.
No, Steve what I really wanted to talk about was Ricky's white suit.
Well let- let- let- let me explain some-

Well- well- well- well- well. Never mind, all that. One, it's actually- I bought it for a photoshoot cause I'm doing this thing- I've got- I've got a DVD coming out in October and I'm doing a- I'm doing a spoof of the front cover of Thriller. So I bought a white suit--
And I got it, right? And I thought well I might as well wear that then now and get it dry-cleaned.
I thought you blagged it, you see.
And I thought- I thought when I put it on- I thought I looked a bit like Sean Connery as James Bond. Apparently I--

Pacifism. Sometimes you have to- have to vent, so it's not clear and you gotta go- 'Okay, let's make it easier for you. What do you think of the little black one in Sugar Babes?' Which is brilliant. She hates War. That's me. That's me done then.
Exactly. Has that helped sway you're uh- your point?
Yeah. Yeah. But I don't know, when [unsure]

Do you remember when- when the uh, that young au pair was over in, uhm, in America, and she got, she got in arrested for the murder, or the death, rather, of that, of that young child, I forget her name. Do you remember that story?
Well do you remember there was a whole section in the paper there, where there was, uhm, I think it was members of Coronation Street saying 'release her, please release her'.
I remember you said you fancied her?
You said you fancied her when it was all happening.
He- he- he- he said, he said 'I think it was the danger'. [Ricky laughs]
There was none of that, do you know what I thought it was?
I would love, I would love you to go out with Louise Woodward.
The thing about Wooders is that she, um, my suspicion was, my suspicion was that when she came back and she had been cleared of it
She hadn't been cleared of it!
I don't think she- I think they just let her out-
No, it was just she'd done her time, and it was, it was, I think it was manslaughter. I- I'm not sure about this
We are teetering on the edge of getting-
Well if someone knows, call up- we don't know this so don't- don't-
Yeah but I think you're right, I think you're right, she-

Well, either way, it was a tragic, tragic accident, and uh, she wasn't a murderer, that was the clear point. And it just struck me, that, um, that nevertheless there would probably be a certain stigma.

Y'know, she was down, y'know, kind of Monrose on a Wednesday night, looking for a dance, and probably there weren't gonna be a lot of guys queueing up for her because they were conscious that, you know, she had a certain reputation, whereas ding dong, gentleman Steve
Yeah. You know what, I'd let her babysit, because she'd never- she'd be so careful wouldn't she? You know what I mean? She'd be on her real best behaviour.
Maybe we shouldn't be talking about it [Ricky laughs]
But I do wonder what- I do wonder what she's up to now.
If you're a lawyer and we've said something wrong, let us know now and we'll apologise quickly, uh, you know.
Anyway, good luck to you, Louise, if you're out there listening, good luck and, you know, ricky.gervais@xfm.co.uk
I don't want- I don't want my name attached in case-
Yeah? You're free tonight, aren't you?
Yeah, I'm free. I'm free for the next eight years [Ricky laughs].
Sure, sure, sure, sure, sweet, sweet, sweet, sweet, 10-storey loves stong- uhh- love stong? Ha, yeah, 10-storey love stong, from, uh, the Stone Doses.
Yeah, see, it's not as easy as it looks, is it?
It's not and I'll tell you it's also because I'm a little under the weather still.
Yeah, that's my- yeah, that's my excuse.
You've had a week off. Concentrate.
I mean, I've got cable TV, but there is nothing on, is there, in the- in the daytime? It is just, I mean, I loved 'Today with Des and Mel' that's brillaint.
Was Joe Pascuale on again? He always pops up. I love it when he pops up.
Genuinely, without irony, I really like Joe Pascuale.
Do you know him? Have you met him?
I haven't, no I haven't, no. But I really really like him. I think he's really funny.
And one of his favourite- one of his jokes that I've always enjoyed is, um, 'why is there a lock on the door of the 24/7?'.
It's good, he's a thoughtful man.
I just like his squeaky voice. I don't like the jokes.
Yeah, but you know, I only caught the end, the other day, it was brilliant, but um, Des was-
Singing a medley of Buddy Holly songs.
He doesn't quite sing, does he? It's like pulling your punch.
Do you know what I mean? He can't actually.
It's not actually singing, it's talking, it's talking the words
But he knew buddy apparently and he toured with him-
Ricky interrupts Steve to continue impersonating Des O'Connor
He never quite finishes, it's lovely, like he's got no breath.
But it's the adverts in between-
Yeah, he's a good looking man.
Yeah, I think so. Yeah he's doing well.
Raise your glasses, and all you listening at home.
I'd love to see him interview Louise Woodward.
Do you want to hear some Louise Woodward- I have had some calls.
But I don't know if they're true or not though. What did you hear?
I think one them was that she was studying law.
No, we mustn't say that shop that she works in.

No, no, no, wouldn't say that. But I'm sure I read the same thing Steve, someone said they read she was studying law and I think I read that because she knows so much about it, so she decided to go and study it herself.
Never know when it will come in useful.
But she has been spotted in various parts of the country selling all manner of things.
We've got to stop this now, we've got to stop this now, it's not fair.
It's all water under the bridge.
Um, anyway, uh, um, let's play a record. Let's play record. I'll talk about it later.
We've just got ourselves in trouble, I think we just need to go and consult our lawyers.
Would you like some Peter Gabriel?
Ahh, this is a beautiful track, and this was actually in Vanilla Sky, so a bit of resurgence, this is Solsbury Hill.
Peter Gabriel. What a lovely track that is. Solsbury Hill on XFM 104.9.
Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Claire Sturgess.
You know, if Karl was here, you know what he'd want now?
It's what Karl would have wanted.
Placebo, the bitter end. XFM 104.9 I'm Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Claire Sturgess in for Karl Pilkington who's in Madeira.
Indeed. Is that where the cakes from?
Yep, that's what it's named after I think
I don't know where Madeira is.
Do a lot of old people go there?
There are a lot of old people there. There are a lot of old people.
Well Karl is essentially a 50 year old man in the body of a 30 year old.
I know yeah, I think it-
Whooaah. Party by the pool it was, it was actually really good, I much prefer that than uh. We went to Greece once and we wondered in this place.

By mistake going through and it was just full of people in Everton shirts and Liverpool shirts and just drinking lager and ohhh, where's the fun in that? The idea of Butlins, just millions of families screaming around would drive me mental.
Butlins is the most extraordinary place I've ever been to, I went there with a bunch of friends-
We can't slag it off, but not Butlins specifically just any, anything.
No, I'm not slagging Butlins off, but it was just an extraordinary place. The bars, themed, one bar themed.
But a- a tribute band to Status Quo playing.

It was extraordinary. So you walk in the swing doors. (Imitates swing doors). And there's Status Quo playing and everyone else is- all the staff dressed in cowboy outfits uh, and cowgirl outfits uh, serving drinks.

I've told you this before, but I sneaked into Butlin's, we- we sneaked in one night and we didn't know what was on, and they were serving lager and chips and there's just loads of families and- and lots of Northern men in short sleeve shirts and kids running around (incoherent). And uh--
So they just arrange the chairs in the sort of dance hall and they went, 'And now, ladies and gentlemen, the entertainment for this evening is David Copperfield, not the magician'.
And it was the bloke from uh, Three of a Kind.

He came out. He did it all. He did all the jokes. He did all the 'and how are you? Oh, you're nice', you know, to people in the audience and then his finale was, he stood on a chair because there wasn't a stage and he did Classical Gas. Seriously. On guitar.
And then they clo- went like that- and he went- thanks-- (incoherent).
And they stop clapping and he came back on to get his jacket.
Yeah. Okay. There- there was also a girl boy duo in blue satin called Joint Effort

Which I was loving. And at the end, right? It was on, I think it was on a Saturday night. So uh, people were leaving sort of the next day or Friday night, and leaving the next day and uh, the kids and that was sort of like going up to the Redcoats and they were crying, right? And all the Redcoats and Joint Effort and uh-
They did. We Are the World.
Amazing. What an amazing night that was.
Joint Effort. I don't think-- I saw a documentary. I'm sure I saw a documentary, which is finding out what uh the likes of David Copperfield are up to now.
And he was a thatcher, wasn't he? Wasn't he mending roofs?
I think so, yeah. I think you're right yeah.
And I'm sure I saw him saying- they said, 'Would you not- well you know, would you not want to be back on Primetime TV?'. And he said, 'Do you know, I- I think I prefer mending roofs.
No, he's probably the same as uh, David Van Day when he did that advert um, when he said uh, 'It got to the point where I prefer to sell Burgers than records'.
You never preferred selling burgers, David.
Have you watched any of the Reborn in the USA?
See- I've missed it and I'm gutted.
Absolutely love it. I reckon it's Hadley or Cox. It's Hadley or Cox all the way.
Um, eh, "We close our eyes. We never do'. Him.
What band is that? What band is that?
Yeah. He- he's- he's probably the best singer in a sort of standard cabaret way.
And- and how does it work? Do they get voted out as they go round?
So it's Sonia who's gone is it?
No, there's two- two uh, from um the studio audience, two are nominated. The low- lowest. I think the lowest people and then then uh Britain. People in Britain--
Vote one uh back on the bus.
Can I just ask Why they're doing it in the States? Why don't they just do it in this country?
Well, because it was meant to be relaunched their career without prejudice.
And also as an excuse to go to America, I suppose and people not know him. Although fame is creeping in. I think a lot of people recognise Tony Hadley.
Particularly when he sang true at karaoke.
Um, so uh. No but uh um yeah.
Is he as good as ever?
He's fine. He's a bit dramatic but he's all right. It's--
Any of these faces familiar to you. Did you ever bump into them?
No, you never saw- you never hung out with Hadley or?
No, no, we all lived in the same house.
Yeah, you did. Didn't you have a run in with Bucks Fizz?

Once- well once when we had to- when we were going up to do- we were going up to do um- a- um, a TV show um, and our A&R man had just forgotten about us and we were there. We were at the- we were at the airport. We didn't have the tickets and so Bucks Fizz-

Were doing the same show and that- I remember they tried to smuggle us through. They had sort of like them and their crew. And they just like showed us the tickets. They went through and they went, 'well', like- like that would work. They went (incoherent) oh sorry.
As if the two girls stand in the lobby, whip off their skirts.
Everyone was sidetracked while you legged it through.
Well- well, I was on the shoulders of uh-
Bobby G and wearing a really long coat and I went, 'Bobby (incoherent' and he went, 'Yes, I am taller now'
You're a lot taller uh in flesh than you are on Top of the Pops.
You weren't fat then, no no you're right.
Yeah, no, but I love it. And the other thing I've be watching is American pop Idol.
Last night. It's great. Really good. Yeah.
Is it- this is Simon Cowell?
Claire speaks incoherently in the background.
Is that- is that one that Geri Halliwell is part of?
No, no, this is um uh Randy Jackson, 'What's up, dog?'. Um, Paula Abdul and Simon Cowell. But Simon Cowell makes so much more sense in that context-
Cause they're all, you- you know 'You're great'. And they do people, they stand up and they clap and he goes, 'Oh sit down, it was all right.
And it makes so much more sense, you know what I mean? I mean over here it's a bit of a pantomime sort of drama queen but over there he's suddenly-
He's the sort of the voice of reason.
The voice of sanity. Exactly. Yeah. Yeah. But um that's- that's the trash TV that I watched.
Yeah. But no Reborn's funny. But again, once again; public are stupid, they voted out um Dollar that was driving everyone mad. And there was fights. They why did they--
Did they really? Cause they really went after Sonia.
Well yeah because you know- oh yeah they really went for it.
I don't think the public should be allowed to vote on TV shows. I don't think they know what's best for them.
It does strike me that, like, in the Golden Age of EastEnders, if people had said, do you want to vote out uh Dirty Den? They'd have gone, 'Yeah, he's nasty'.
I know. Yeah, that- it's that confusion either with, with entertainment and punish these people, yeah, they should keep them in and then make them lose.
Yeah. So you've had all the the best of both worlds.
What about the new celebrity- I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here?
Now, who's in that? The one--
Uh, Antony Worrall Thompson, why? Why does he wanna- (incoherent)
You gotta have someone- someone that can cook, in't ya?
Yeah, the girl from Changing Rooms.
Phil Tufnell, cricketer. I'm gonna put some money on him to win.
I reckon he's going to win. Cause apparently he's sort of funny and- and nice and everything. And uh- yeah.
Would you ever- would you ever do any of those celebrity things?
I do think- I genuinely think if you were in the

I was a bit feverish, as well, in the week. And I, um... at one point I s- I- I had a real, kind of, movie s- I- if I'm ill, I like to be like you're ill in the movies. And I was tossing and turning in bed, I had the fever, I was waking up, I was sweating. All sorts. And I- and I keep waking up really early, and I was watching daytime TV for hours, and um... the adverts that you see in the daytime... I mean, we kn- because we do actually work. A lot of people think we just doss around all day, but we do actually work, and so I don't get to see TV in the day much. And the adverts... it's not adverts you see at night! And during breaks-
A lot of them are ei- are either aimed at- they're either aimed at people who- who basically are- are waiting to die.
That- I love that advert. "Waiting to die?"
Well they are a bit like that!

I mean, there's a couple... There's one with, uh, Christopher Timothy, he's sat in a pub on his own, just having a pint in the afternoon. I think this was before he um... I think this was before he uhh... became a doctor. He, um-
'e's havin' a pint on his own, looking through the, you know, the John Ads,
He's had a good career, hasn't he? Vet, doctor... Brilliant. I-I-
I think he's always wanted to play a lawyer.
And he- and he basically says, in so many words, I can't- I can't remember it verbatim, but he basically says: "you know, um, you're- you're probably getting on a bit... uhm..."
"You- you're not going to be around forever... you could drop dead tomorra'..."
"Have you- have you made provisions for your children and your family and your wife?" And-
And I think you at home are supposed to have gone "oh, christ, I haven't!"
And "I might- I was feeling my testicles earlier, they are a bit lumpy!"
Oh no! You know, or [coughs] "I've got a bit of a cough..."
And I- and "I had to bend down quite low to feel them!"
"So, uh, you know, I am getting on a bit!"
"In fact, what I do now is pull them towards me and kick 'em up..."
"... and on the way back down I have a quick feel!"
Um... o-or, yeah, or when the kids come to visit.
"Where have you put 'em? Where have you put 'em?" [in a childlike voice] "We've put 'em on the mantleshelf-" "Oh! You little devils, go on with you! D'you want a Werther's Original?"

And, uh, that's another advert you see constantly, Werther's Originals. Um- but, um... so they've got those, and then they've got the adverts, which I always love, which are- are adverts for, um, any kind of, you know, Claims Direct or any of those things, it's just...

...invariabley, there's a reconstruction of- of an accident that might happen: someone tripping over a paving slab... there's one which is particularly chilling, of a guy who, um, I think he- he- he's with his kid watching football, and you're thinking to himself, you know, "aw I bet you-" he's looking, he's thinking "I wish I could join in." And it flashes back, and there he is up a ladder. Uh, on a very shiny surface, with no one supporting it, frankly, which is- which is-
Frankly, I- I- I blame him. And then it- it- it topples. For no reason. I don't know why it topples.
I all- whenever I see it, I always think-
I hope he never walks again.
Well, it... he falls off it, um-
Did he smash his face in?
Did he fall on a spike? Because if he's gonna go up that ladder on a shiny surface...
...with no one holding it, right... did he fall-? Did he crack-? Did he fall backwards on his head? The little fff...
Right, did he- did he do the splits and crush his nuts? The fff...
He made a considerable lump sum of cash, thanks to the efforts of one of those claims companies.
All right, he's negligence has seen him...
Hold on, Steve was there a Yokel with a pitchfork looking up as he fell on it?
It fell off. I think he must have bruised his ankle or sprained a ligament
Aah, that's no not enough! That hasn't taught him anything!
Well, it's not taught him a lesson. In fact, if anything it is encouraging to just to be more foolhardy in the future.
Cause if you're gonna dish out 5, 3-5 grand willy-nilly to these, these people.
These lunatics, these oaths. These simpletons.

Do you know my favourite advert is the one sort of the back of the those glossy magazines, you get given away. And it was always an old woman and she'd fallen like, in her you know, you know, front porch or whatever and she was just reaching out what she was too weak, to reach the phone. So, it's like you carry little button around with you that you press. I love the idea that. She looked so vulnerable, with my...
I always feel with those kind of those claims adverts. That it's almost like, saying, I'm not going to say it explicitly.
Here are some ideas for you.
You know, paving slabs... Is there one near you?
Could you have a little trip?
I'm not saying anything, but maybe read between the lines...
There is money to be made.
Do you knows those adverts in the back of those... Remember Innovations catalog?
Well, I just read this week.
Innovations catalog is being, being closed down.
Innovations catalog, which used to go to something like 50 million homes or something
I tell you what, I love the Innovations Catalog.
You do feel like "I could do with that"

No, I do, I want to spend money on an advantage in life. Like, you know, I want the power packs and the hover boards, and things like "Want to see through walls? Just for 19.99!" they don't work do they...
I bought oxygen. Cause I was
What do you mean you bought oxygen?
Well, me and my mate, it was sort of like, I don't know, 1987. Me and my mate Wally.
We were doing distance, long distance running together. We're trying to get good and I thought, I just have some oxygen before the race
Well, then get some oxygen, it's there, free in the air. What are you talking about?
No it was in big canisters
A canister of oxygen? What was that gonna do?
It didn't work, it just smelled like you were sniffing mints. I didnt, I couldn't get any in.
But what was it supposed to do?
Well, you know oxygenate your blood, so you can
Yeah. I don't know why. I
I don't know, I can't remember.
It was 19.99. It was a big cannister.
Why did you buy it, Claire?
I mean, he was at least doing a jog.
But it does seem to me... The problem with the Innovations Catalog, is that for the the few idiots that buy stuff like you, there are hundreds-thousands, who just look through it and laughed.
At the absurdity of, you know, a motorized tie rack.
Who is so lazy that they need that?
I worked for a while, uh answering the the mail, opening the mail for a returns.

It wasn't the Innovations people but it was a much - it was - if that's the kind of middle class version, this was a very much more working class, um, thing. It was you know, how to, you know, how to get hot dogs out of a tin and all the rest of it. And there was stuff in there that was incredible. There was one item that was in the catalogue and it was, uh - I know, like me, you've probably thought to yourself; 'I just haven't got time to boil the kettle and fill up my hot water bottle.'
You've thought 'That takes upwards of a minute and a half to do.'
What I need is some kind of state of the art, kind of plastic container with some kind of blue gel inside, which I put in the microwave and that heats up.

So that's what this device was - you put it in the microwave, you buzz it in there for like 30 seconds, saving yourself, you know, a minute of preparation time. And we used to get them sent back. I swear to God, they'd be sent back, they'd be split, old women saying 'Uh, I heated this up in the microwave, I went to sleep - it split asunder and the blue gel scorched my legs. I've got third-degree burns.'
Old woman? With a scolding? Call Claims Direct!

So I'd have to send replacements back to these old women who had scolded their legs. We didn't even send them their money back, we just sent them a replacement. I mean, unbelievable. Unbelievable. Sometimes, I always thought -
